doc.source_uri: 2025-08-31/India Telecoms RIL 2025 AGM highlights and key takeaways for telecom sectorIndia Telecoms RIL 2025 AGM highlights and ke_2025-08-31

passages.text: August 31, 2025 10:33 PM GMT
India Telecoms | Asia Pacific

Key highlights from RIL's AGM: a) Jio's IPO in 1HF26, b) taking home grown technology to outside India, c) update on JioPC, Jio AI Cloud and early look into upcoming products such as JioFrames (wearable product), e) JV with Meta Platforms and partnership with Google announced.

Our views: Reliance Jio has been positioned to transform into a deep tech company where the entire technology stack is built indigenously. 2025 AGM highlighted ambitious goals for Jio in taking this stack beyond connectivity to multiple new service streams e.g., a) AI offerings through global strategic partnerships, b) Cloud- enabled JioPC, c) Wearable device platforms, d) ambition to take the technology to countries outside India.

We believe India Telecom operators are benefiting from: a) ARPU repair cycle - we expect tariff hikes to continue (we have assumed one in 1HFY27). We believe announcement of timing of Jio IPO reinforces confidence on our assumption of industry repair cycle, b) Accelerated roll outs of 5G and widespread adoption - near term use case has been accelerating FWA roll outs, c) India telcos going beyond connectivity to build multiple revenue streams - both Airtel and Jio talked about their own cloud offerings. Overall, we believe strong and large India telcos shall continue to see strong EBITDA CAGR over the coming years.
1. Reliance Jio's IPO in 1HF26: Reliance Industries Chairman announced that Jio is making all arrangements to file for its IPO by 1HF26.
2. Significant 5G adoption: As per the company, Jio crossed the milestone of 500m subscribers (vs 498mn at QE Jun'25). Of these, \(\sim 220mn\) are 5G users, up \(\sim 70\%\) yoy from 199mn in 2024.

3. Accelerating home broadband adoption via AirFiber: Jio's proprietary UBR broadband technology has revolutionized home broadband, offering GB speeds while avoiding disruptions from cable and supporting high-end applications. Jio AirFiber has become the largest FWA service provider globally, achieving the target of adding 1mn homes every month, that it set last year.

4. Enterprise customers to drive next leg of growth for Jio, as per the company. The company is working on creating simple, scalable and secure platforms for MSMEs and enterprises ranging from franchise management to AI-based solutions, which will enable it to compete globally.
MORGAN STANLEY INDIA COMPANY PRIVATE LIMITED+
Asia Pacific Industry View

\(+ =\) Analysts employed by non- U.S. affiliates are not registered with FINRA, may not be associated persons of the member and may not be subject to FINRA restrictions on communications with a subject company, public appearances and trading securities held by a research analyst account.

5. Going global: Jio plans to deploy its innovative technologies globally, with strategic partnerships, creating value for its partners and shareholders alike. Reliance Industries has also entered into a 70:30 JV with Meta Platforms for Enterprise AI solutions, with both companies jointly committing Rs8.55bn (US\(100mn) in the JV company. Powered by Meta's open source Lama models, it will build and scale enterprise AI solutions for enterprises in India and select international markets.

- On Jio AI Cloud, the company had announced up to 100GB free cloud storage for all Jio users and it has 40mn + users using Jio AI Cloud. It unveiled the next gen of Jio AI Cloud, as an AI-powered memory companion, that can help users: i) find and relive past moments, with voice search in their own language, ii) organize better, by automatically categorizing images, e.g., by putting Aadhar image under identity documents, iii) create shareable reels, promo videos etc, with no expert skills required.- On JioPC, the company had announced a cloud computing solution that transforms any TV into an AI-ready computer by connecting a keyboard to the Jio Set-Top Box with no up-front investment and a pay for what you use model. It enables users to remotely upgrade its memory, storage, and computing power based on their needs. Jio is also partnering with leading providers to offer a rich library of out-of-the-box applications, & powerful AI tools to boost productivity and creativity.

7. Launch of JioFrames, an AI powered wearable platform, with: i) multilingual AI voice-assistant supporting multiple Indian languages, ii) hands free photo/video capture capabilities with instant storage on Jio AI Cloud, iii) AI assistance while reading, cooking etc, with built in open-ear speakers, which enable users to take calls, listen to music etc, while maintaining environmental awareness.

8. Formation of Reliance Intelligence, Reliance Industries' wholly owned subsidiary, which has been set up to house: i) India's AI infrastructure, ii) global partnerships, iii) talent for AI and to build AI services in India. It will build gigawatt-scale, AI-ready data centers in Jamnagar powered by green energy, engineered for AI training and inference and connected by Jio's network. RIL's chairman also announced a partnership for AI with Google, which will help all Reliance's businesses transform using AI. Together, they are establishing Jamnagar Cloud region, built for and dedicated to Reliance, wherein Google will bring its world-class AI and compute from Google Cloud and innovate with Reliance on advanced AI initiatives.

Morgan Stanley uses a relative rating system using terms such as Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated or Underweight (see definitions below). Morgan Stanley does not assign ratings of Buy, Hold or Sell to the stocks we cover. Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated and Underweight are not the equivalent of buy, hold and sell. In addition, since Morgan Stanley Research contains more complete information concerning the analyst's views, investors should carefully read Morgan Stanley Research, in its entirety, and not infer the contents from the rating alone. In any case, ratings (or research) should not be used or relied upon as investment advice. The Stock Ratings described below apply to Morgan Stanley's Fundamental Equity Research and do not apply to Debt Research produced by the Firm. For disclosure purposes only (in accordance with FINRA requirements), we include the category headings of Buy, Hold, and Sell alongside our ratings of Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated and Underweight. Morgan Stanley does not assign ratings of Buy, Hold or Sell to the stocks we cover. Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated and Underweight are not the equivalent of buy, hold, and sell but represent recommended relative weightings (see definitions below). To satisfy regulatory requirements, we correspond Overweight, our most positive stock rating, with a buy recommendation; we correspond Equal- weight and Not- Rated to hold and Underweight to sell recommendations, respectively.

Data include common stock and ADRs currently assigned ratings. Investment Banking Clients are companies from whom Morgan Stanley received investment banking compensation in the last 12 months. Due to rounding off of decimals, the percentages provided in the % of total' column may not add up to exactly 100 percent.

Overweight (O). The stock's total return is expected to exceed the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Equal-weight (E). The stock's total return is expected to be in line with the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Not-Rated (NR). Currently the analyst does not have adequate conviction about the stock's total return relative to the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Underweight (U). The stock's total return is expected to be below the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.
Unless otherwise specified, the time frame for price targets included in Morgan Stanley Research is 12 to 18 months.
Attractive (A). The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months to be attractive vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.

In-Line (I). The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months to be in line with the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.Cautious (C). The analyst views the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months with caution vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.Benchmarks for each region are as follows: North America - S&P 500; Latin America - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI Latin America Index; Europe - MSCI Europe; Japan - TOPIX; Asia -relevant MSCI country index or MSCI sub-regional index or MSCI AC Asia Pacific ex Japan Index.
